Physics is all around us! Without studying physics, we wouldn’t be able to engineer bikes or cars that could safely transport us. In this lesson, we’ll be learning about some of the physics that surround the operation of cars.

Friction is the the force responsible for the resistance you feel when you drag your feet. The more force you put on another object or surface, the more friction force you’ll experience. For example, try pushing your palm against a table and dragging it. Now try doing it without pushing very hard. Which instance was it easier to drag your hand?
Now let’s friction in action with the race car!. Try driving the car around a little bit with the joystick. Take note of how fast it can go.
Now try adding two weights onto it and driving. Is it slower?
Now try adding two MORE weights. Is it slower now?
Once more, but let’s really turn up the friction. Try adding FOUR more weights now. How does the speed compare to the car without weights?

Congratulations! You’ve now applied concepts of friction. Now let’s consider another force. Imagine turning a door knob. Can you name the force you are applying to the door knob? The force responsible is named torque!

Okay, now let’s consider what is responsible for moving the RC Car. We know that when we drive the car the wheels move the car forward. Furthermore, the wheels do this through spinning. Therefore, it must be a torque force that is ultimately responsible for the movement of the car!
We have capped the amount of torque that can be applied to the RC Car’s wheels. Try driving the car and notice how much torque is being applied as shown by the torque bar on the bottom.
We’ve now increased the amount of torque the RC Car can apply to the wheels. Now see how fast it can go. You should notice that the more torque applied, the faster the car goes!

Congratulations! You’ve now learned how friction and torque work and apply to cars! These are concepts that many different professions have to apply, such as the engineers that create cars! Feel free to play with the joystick and weights and see friction and torque in action again!

Computers are becoming a bigger and bigger part of our world! One of the ways that computers are controlled is through programming. Programmers give computers a task list of things to do which eventually lead to what you’re seeing on the screen now! In this lesson, you’ll be learning the basics of programming!

Writing tasks for a computer to do is called coding. Unlike people, computers can’t understand English so programmers have to give them tasks in a language they can understand. For your first task, let’s start with something simple. We’ll be telling the computer in the car what to do so we must first declare the thing we’ll be working with. The general form of this is “ITEMTYPE ObjectName” Like English, we have to end all of our sentences with a punctuation mark, which is “;” instead of a period. So try declaring your first object! (Type “Vehicle RCCar;”)

Great! Now the computer knows you want to work with an object called RCCar. When we want to tell the computer to do something with an object, we can add the command to the end of the object. Try typing “RCCar.drive();” to see what happens!
Awesome! See that? We gave the computer the instruction to drive the car and so it did! What if the car is starting to hit a wall? Let’s stop it. Type RCCar.stop();
